It helped me understand why my father told us nothing about his experiences in the artillery of WWII. Jack Firebrace, the best trench digger was by far the most compelling character."It was not his death that mattered; it was the way the world had been dislocated. It was not all the tens of thousands of deaths that mattered; it was the way they had proved that you could be human yet act in a way that was beyond nature." (p. 225)“No child or future generation will ever know what this was like…When it is over we will go quietly among the living and we will not tell them…We will seal what we have seen in the silence of our hearts and no words will reach us.” (p. 403)And yet, Sebastian Faulks attempts to tell us.

Like most people I've known about this classic for years, but having not been made to read it on my school syllabus, just figured it would probably be boring. I've never had an interest in the first world war, Im not a pro war individual and find it depressing that so many men died needlessly...yes I'm one of those horrible individuals who act like it never happened and change the subject from those whose lives were turned upside down by it! Not because I don't respect it, because the idea of facing such a thing scares the living crap out of me!It took me a while to get into Birdsong and I didn't like being tossed around from past to present. Apart from the end present chapter I think I would have preferred that it remain a book of the past. I know the point of the future is how much we don't grasp what occurred, but we really couldn't, and that knowledge is what left me with an aching feeling throughout Stephen's tale. Part of me is bereft of feeling - numbed with knowledge, but lacking in true understanding - whilst the rest of me was grateful to never have known such times.How can you not like this book? You'd have to have no heart to turn away from the lessons that it asks of you. Yet it's not a joyful one to me. It's about survival, relationships and human nature, set in a time when these were really tested. To me today it adds nothing but the knowledge of what was before. A beautifully written book, a lesson to be taken into account and nothing but an after feeling of guilt.

This is a truely wonderful book.The story is a complex and passionate one involving love, loss, betrayal and the horrors and chaos of the First World War. It is also a story of survival and the strength of the human spirit and is set in three different time frames: France 1910, France 1916-18 and England 1978-79 and all of these are linked in some way to the central character Stephen Wraysford.This is a beautifully written book but it is not a light read. It is passionate, intense, meaningful and at times deeply unsettling. The horrors of the First World War are brought vividly to life by the author and these scenes are some of the most harrowing I have ever read in a book. It was also fascinating to see the lengths these men went to in order to try and survive the war and how they tried to make sense of and justify the things they saw, the things they heard and the things they did all in the name of king, country and their fellow soldiers.This is one of the best stand-alone novels I have ever read and even though it is a fairly long book at 500+ pages, I could hardly put it down and completed it in less than two days. This is an immensely powerful novel, one that has to be picked up and read to be truly understood and believed. I highly recommend it and would say that pretty much anyone would enjoy it but if you have an interest in the history of the First World War or you like romance or books that really delve into what makes humans act and think the way they do then you are in for a real treat with this gem of a book.

Diluted to it's essence, this book is about one man's salvation and how it moves through the people around him forward and backward in time. Nuanced characters and powerfully detailed descriptions, a compelling read about the foibles of war and the pathos it spreads in it's wake. From the book: He felt the dry, turned earth beneath his boots as he picked his way back toward the British lines. A lark was singing in the unharmed air above him. His body and mind were tired beyond speech and beyond repair, but nothing could check the low exultation of his soul.

One of the best books I have ever read. I am still reading it and dreading finishing it. So far it is in my top 5 books I have read.After much procrastination I have finally finished reading this story. To be honest I have never read much about the first world war, nor have I ever had any interest in reading about it, especially in relation to the actual battles. However, this story makes you feel it, you want to read what happens to these characters you learn about, the words evoke so much emotion, the smells, the pictures you envision of the people, men climbing up out of trenches facing certain death, it is heartrending, heartbreakingly realistic in the telling, to the point where I had to put the book down on several occasions because the brutality of it all was too overwhelming. You cannot help but feel overcome by the stark choices that were forced on the boys in the front lines, the guilt of those who survived, and the fear yet gratefulness of those in the tunnels. The story of love, loss, and the brutality of war told in a hauntingly beautiful way that lingers with you long after you finish reading it. This is one of those stories I will definitely read again, and one of the few books that have earned the place in my heart that means I must own, never throw away, and definitely will read again-not many books are marked as keepers in my life, but this is definitely one of them.

This haunting novel weaves the tragedies of war, lost love, death and utter hoplessness. The idyllic beauty of the French countryside (with a minor disruption here and there from unions) is enhanced with the passionate romance between Isabelle and Stephen. The tension between them is captured beautifully by Faulks...and their end is just as poignant. Faulks shows Stephen's capability for both love and loss. His humanity is completely torn from him during the war. The horrors soldiers faced not just from the enemy, but from living in trenches with the constant fear and degradation of being more animal than human was horrifying. By also following the miners, Faulks adds the real terror the men faced both above and below ground...even when they managed to grasp some humanity from the men around them, they were almost all killed, leaving the survivors behind with only terrifying memories. When the novel skips to late 1970s London--commemorating the 60th anniversary of the armistice--it takes on a completely different tone. Chasing the past, Stephen's grandaughter struggles to make a connection to him. I didn't really connect with her character...it was hard to leave the emotion Stephen evokes and transfer it onto this new voice. Thankfully, her sections were brief...and wasn't even used in the PBS adaptation of the book, which is what had me reading it in the first place. Despite this, the story was gripping and I enjoyed it very much.

Birdsong is a novel of the First World War, including the Battle of the Somme in France.The novel opens just prior to the war, where a young Englishman, Stephen Wraysford is staying at the home of a French businessman, while learning business methods from him. He falls head over heels for Mr. Azaire's wife, Isabel, and a sordid affair is borne - the couple eventually running off together. After a few happy months, Isabel abruptly leaves him, with no explanation. This part of the novel was just "meh" for me. I wasn't drawn to these characters and rather than feel any sort of sympathy, their actions turned me off.During the war, Stephen is sent to France and endures some of the more brutal and mentally troubling war scenes I have encountered about World War I. They say that this war was so much more terrible for the combatants than other wars (although all wars are hell). This book helps the reader to understand why. Despite the author's semi-detachment to his characters, those scenes make you really feel for all the soldiers, not just the main character. Perhaps the detached writing style was necessary in order to help the reader stomach the war scenes.By the end of the novel, I found myself hoping Stephen would live and likewise, hoping he would die, thus ending his misery. I'm glad to finally read a World War I novel that helped me to understand exactly what it was like for the boys in the trenches.

I wish we could do half stars, as I'd lean toward 3 1/2 for this one. The writing is beautiful, and the sections dealing with WWI are pretty astounding. Stephen, who I disliked in the first section, becomes gradually more layered and sympathetic. The characterizations of the other soldiers are very good, particularly Weir. However, the entire subplot involving Elizabeth should have been cut. I understand that the idea was to demonstrate the connectedness of multiple generations, but it wasn't terribly effective and could have been done more effectively through the character of Francoise, and in a manner more immediate to the main action. I actually liked Elizabeth, but she didn't belong in this book. I was also a bit confused by Isabelle's actions: in the first section, she really gripped me and I understood her actions and why she undertook them. But her later decisions seemed extremely contradictory in the context of her character as previously set forward. In general I also felt like the book wasn't terribly balanced - it felt as if Faulks got caught up in the War, and so he rushes the resolution to the threads set out at the beginning of the novel. I also found the character whose perspective closes the book to be annoying and cannot for the life of me understand why Faulks chose this character to end his novel.

You guys, you guys, guess what? Did you know that WAR IS BAD? Me neither! Sigh. This book is so dumb. Just trite, and silly, and melodramatic. The symbolism is clumsy and cheesy - there are always birds singing after someone has sex or someone dies. I mean, really? The love affair is a little bit ridiculous. It was kind of interesting while it happened, but mostly it was just Stephen idolizing this completely unrealistic woman. The war bits were more realistic, but no more original. So many pages about how awful war is, but that's really nothing new, is it? There's something obnoxious and preachy about the constant war-is-hell-but-let-me-wax-oh-so-tragically-poetic-about-it stuff. And the modern character who apparently just realizes at like thirty years old that World War I was, you know, kind of bad. Give me a break. I wanted to smack her in the face.Anyways, I kind of want to see the miniseries just because I adore Eddie Redmayne, but story-wise, this story was not really worth it. Neither the romance nor the historical aspect was in any way compelling. The writing could be really good, but it wasn't enough to make this book worth it for me.

I can’t help thinking what a better book this would have been had Faulks had a better editor. I almost drowned in all the excess verbiage. Faulks seemed to ascribe to the idea that if a thing is worth saying once it’s worth saying again. And again. And again. Also, description is all well and good to set scene, but need we have pounds and pounds of description that doesn’t help the story along at all?Agree with everyone who says that the first section was slow. I almost threw in the towel. The war sections were indeed the best. I’ve read countless books and seen many films about WWI, and yet I never knew about the tunnels. Still, the whole thing was way too repetitive. The same thing seemed to be happening over and over and over. I’m sure it was true, but it’s the job of the writer to make us feel and understand this without repeating every single detail over and over and over. I almost went mad.The birth scene at the end was the silliest scene I’ve read in a long time.I guess I’d sum up this book as interesting, but not nearly the book it could have been.

I read several other Faulks novels before this one, and only found it because a reviewed had mentioned liking Birdsong and Charlotte Gray much better. I am so glad i read both. i think Birdsong is a fine novel in many ways. There are a few flaws, but on the whole it's absolutely worth reading.It was written in the 70's which is kind of obvious in the way women are portrayed--a bit needy, weak and shallow--i think this is how women were viewed since i lived through it :) --funny how the two "modern" characters are both needy, weak, and shallow. I am not sure why Robert and Elizabeth were necessary at all. The story could have come full circle much better without them. They have no point and they're annoying. The sections of the past are very good, and particularly the accounts of WWI. I read a lot of WWI material, including a diary of a French man who survived it and went home to take up his life again.No matter how much you read of it, there is no understanding. You can't smell the mud and the death or hear the cries.

Isabelle is painted as this perfect mysterious woman who is basically longing for a man to "unlock" her. Stephen (aka Sebastian Faulks) has her immediately (and without particularly any contact) erotically obsessed with him. It just reads like a teenage fantasy/soft porn. I did not throw the book at my cats, but I stopped reading it after the first few chapters and never even got to the war part. As others have said, why is this supposed to be a great book? Judged by men, probably.

Review - This is one of the best books I have ever read. The story is poignant and beautiful. The First World War is obviously at the forefront of the story, but I love how it changes from 1910 to during the war to the 1970s. It gives depth across the generations. It really shows what the war was like from a different perspective - both the foot soldiers and the miners. The characters are deep and they have so much going for them and so many problems. I loved both Stephen and Isabelle, and the whole family saga which prefaces the war. This is a beautifully written novel. The descriptions of the battles (WWI) will stick with me for a long time. Faulks does a wonderful job of drawing believable and complicated characters and giving the readers real vision into their psyches. The descriptions of places and events are perfect--not so much detail that it bores the reader, but enough to paint an exact picture in one's mind.  This book is part love story but mostly war story. Generally, I am not attracted to war stories--and this one is gritty and realistic, but I couldn't put it down.  As an aside, you rarely read real literature with real sex, but this novel is a surprising exception.  I was somewhat disappointed with the ending. There was one more loose end that I really wanted to see resolved, and I felt somewhat cheated by not hearing the end of that particular thread. It was a minor thread, but I had high hopes... Apart from that this book did not disappoint. It deserves the acclaim it has received.

One of the most powerful scenes I’ve ever read, felt just like I was in a movie. Such a harrowing and moving depiction of war. It felt quite long - there was some sections I just didn’t really get into but the emotional love story that went alongside sold it for me.

i was going to give this 4 stars and then i sobbed for the last 30 pages and i couldn't give it anything less than 5. this is one of those books where i read the first 100 pages and thought i would hate it and then i read more and more and i couldn't put it down. the first 100 pages were dull and predictable and i really didn't think i would read further and then i reached part 2, france 1916 in the trenches, and for a subject so bleak and horrible it really was so incredible to read about. stephen started off as someone i didn't care about and i grew to love and care for him along with everyone else he met in his time fighting. i didn't really like elizabeth's parts and i really didn't like that it ended with her but i was still crying so much from stephen's last part that i quite enjoyed her final few pages. loved this a lot. could become one of my all time favourites.

BIRDSONG is a skilfully structured, thought provoking, powerfully written novel. The chaos and mayhem of the French and Belgian WW1 battlefields, so vividly and horrifically drawn, prompt the reader to wonder why humans, now as then, continue to act in a way that is “beyond nature.” Thankfully this pessimistic feeling was diminished for me somewhat by Faulk's presentation of the complex character of Stephen Wraysford. His is a character changed and strengthened so unexpectedly and completely by love that even under the burdensome circumstances of war, he responds selflessly and lovingly to those in need around him. Recommended.

The story alternates between the tales of World War I soldiers who worked entirely underground, digging tunnels into each other's territory, never knowing if they would encounter a foe around the next shovelful. Those portions are tense, dramatic, vivid. The other part is a fairly tepid love story. I think Faulkes wanted very much to attract male and female readers and settled on this unwieldy device.

This book starts slowly with a pre-first world war account of the main characters business visit to France and his affair with the young wife of his host. However the account of the first world war is both spell binding and horrifying and you feel like you are actually there. Telling the stories of many types of soldiers wrapped around Stephen's story is very descriptive and interesting. Tying in the past and the present through Stephens granddaughters need to solidify her life through her roots is brilliant. A must read book!

When i started reading this book it was more based around Stephen and his love affair. But then when it moved into his involvement in the tunnels and trenches of the WW1 the author really showed his skill. It was almost like reading an acount from someone who had actually lived through this horrific ordeal of human loss. The detail and feeling that Faulks manages to recreate for the reader shows his brilliant literary prowess. The author drew me into the book from the first pages and held my attention to the very end! You won't be able to forget this book if you should decide to read it.

Thoroughly recommended.

This has to be one of my favourite all time books. The descriptive writing is fantastic, every time I picked up the book. I was transported back in time.
I read this years ago and it has left a lasting impression. It's a must-read, I think - for anyone, about the pain and loss of war and the human spirit.

Maybe the pointlesness of the novel is a subtle comment on WWI, but it failed to make me care. Interesting, if odd, focus on sapping operations, though.

Birdsong, by Sebastian Faulks (1993) Birdsong is a very gripping, good story. It has sold three million copies worldwide, the sort of figure which makes me think twice about what Faulks was trying to achieve with it; my premise being that top quality art and a very wide audience are usually mutually exclusive. Dickens is for me the ultimate example of the writer who never compromised on his art in order to sell books.Birdsong is essentially a story about a European man, who, like millions of others, gets caught up in the First World War. It’s the story of his survival - not of his fight for survival, but almost of his involuntary fate of surviving. Call it luck, call it the gods in their absurdity playing with the fate of a man who actually had far less reason or will to survive than countless others who perished. It is a gripping tale of life in the trenches, graphically punctuated with the grime and gore and inhumanity of the war, the main trait of which is surely, put plainly, the collapse of civilised humanity and the suspension of historical progress in any positive sense. For many who survived the war, their lives were nevertheless over after what they had seen. In the book, the men agree that if there was hope for the future, it could only be for their children, once it was all over – it was obvious to everyone that the war itself was senseless, had no positive purpose, the men were all reduced to an existence conducted at the lowest common denominator of life, namely an obdurate and expressionless feat of endurance. The endurance of something unbearable, and that was their heroism: to hang on and somehow believe in a time when Europe could and would move forward again. Clearly hundreds of thousands of the European men who fought in the 1st World War witnessed the lowest depths to which humanity could fall, the indifference to bestial conditions and the necessary acceptance of the mechanical killing being the worst aspects. Truly the indifference to the horror which they had to show outwardly was a pretence which was necessary in order to keep a grip on the sanity needed to survive. Stephen talks not of a will to survive, but of it being the very nature of war to make it impossible not to survive if one could. It wasn’t that he wanted to live, although he does speak of being interested in how it turns out (but not in who “wins”, nobody could win) and the lengths to which humanity would go in that particular situation. Not that there wasn’t kindness and loyalty and comradeship, there was, as evidenced by the jagged friendship that formed between Stephen and Weir. But in friendships there was danger: since friends could at any moment be obliterated and leave you grieving, which in turn was an additional burden, most men did not form friendships. Comradeship and friendship were strictly separated, friendships generally only evolved if both men were sure they were going to die, as illustrated when Stephen and Jack are trapped in the damaged tunnel towards the end of the book. But perhaps the paradox of life is forever there: there is no reason to live, but you do anyway, and nowhere is this clearer than when men are caught up in a terrible war.But Birdsong is more than just an anti-war tract. It is about the history of 20th Century Europe (a favourite theme of Faulks). We meet Stephen’s granddaughter, who is a middle-class British woman living and working in 1970s London. Her mother, born in France, strangely knows very little about her father (Stephen), although he took an active part in bringing her up (which I though was a bit loose, plot wise) and so Elizabeth starts trying to find out more about him. She finds encoded diaries at her parental home and tries to contact men who knew her grandfather. The ending (which I won’t reveal) is, I think, an attempt at showing that history can be fulfilled, resolved, rounded satisfactorily, and that the chain of human experience (he uses these words) is very difficult to break despite humanity being seemingly determined to destroy it with wanton and bestial acts. I’m not sure the ending works for me, I found it a bit forced and twee, as indeed was the feeling I got whenever the leitmotif of birdsong arose. There was a little too much rather naïve symbolism there for me. Though to be fair, at least it (the birdsong, which arose repeatedly at moments during the narrative) wasn’t too obvious, as symbols go. It wasn’t a symbol of peace or anything as trite as that. It may have been to do with the idea that there is a subliminal but ubiquitous seam of nature that is thoroughly joyous and honest and true and that despite the unnatural acts and horror that humanity perpetrates and commits, we can’t destroy it. Humanity does continue after the war, and even during it people still live on, and even fall in love. Once the war is over, people experience joy and purity again, above all (for Faulks) returning to brotherhood in order to build a new continent, in socio-political terms. In accordance with this seam of nature, Elizabeth loves a married man because of who he is to her (and these feelings are returned, and it doesn’t seem wrong that he is married, because neither of them can stop themselves from loving). This is highlighted when another man outrageously and presumptuously proposes to her on only the third occasion he meets her. Although he is single and “eligible”, Elizabeth doesn’t hesitate a moment in rejecting him, though she is actually more astonished than outraged at his behaviour. Robert is the man for her, married or unmarried....On July 1, 1916, on the first day of the Battle of the Somme, during the infamous Allied offensive described in Birdsong, there were 57,470 Allied casualties, 19,240 of these were dead. Most were massacred in the first hour as wave after wave clambered courageously but hopelessly out of the trenches to be wiped out by German machine gun artillery, who, safe on higher ground and in barbed wire encircled trenches, had simply been waiting for them to come.The First World War killed about 750,000 British soldiers and injured another 1.7 million, meaning that nearly half of the six million conscripts returned dead or injured. The war and its aftermath claimed up to 16 million lives if the at least 8 million victims of the typhoid epidemic and famine in Russia from 1918 to 1922 are included, millions more were crippled. Eight million European soldiers perished. About 750,000 German civilians starved; Germany lost 15% of its active male population. There is speculation that the Spanish flu pandemic of 1918-20, in which at least 50 million people died worldwide was exacerbated and accelerated by conditions caused by the war (massed malnutrition coupled with the increased mobility of the population). These figures shocked millions of Europeans and must have hardened their resolve to change things from their roots - although the 2nd War barely twenty years later obviously interrupted that process. Faulks is aware of the revolution in thinking that these calamitous events caused in the development of Europe as a political continent. It is no exaggeration to say that the nature and extent of the war changed Europe forever. Four empires collapsed, the Bolshevik Revolution was hastened if not precipitated by a mutiny in the Russian navy, the European Union would surely not have come about if it had not been for the collective resolve (finally, after the Second World War!) to achieve continent-wide peace and prosperity brought about by healthy trade between nations to replace petty, isolationist nation-bound rivalry for the benefit of the landed gentry. In the novel, the idea of European unity is hinted at by the fact that Elizabeth’s lover works for the European Parliament in Brussels. It is no co-incidence that Faulks, as a Francophile himself, creates his main character with roots both in England and France, and that one of the main French characters in the novel ends up living with and nursing a German soldier. The scenes near to the end of the novel involving Stephen, who is still in France when the war ends, and the German soldiers (including a Jew, whose brother is killed by Stephen’s attempt to get out of the tunnel by dynamiting the blockage) are deeply moving in their reconciliation and symbolic return to the values of civilised humanity. Europe had to get to this stage in order to mature (in fact, in order to survive) and it did succeed in doing so. Faulks is a barrister by background, and a journalist by profession (he left The Independent newspaper in the early 90s to become a full-time writer). The Independent was and is an important institution of British journalism which he had worked for since its inception a decade earlier, first as literary editor and then later as deputy editor of the Independent on Sunday. One of the founding tenets of this newspaper was and is the belief in Europe as a political entity, at a time when this was quite a radical concept in Britain (this is no longer the case, despite what the gutter press prints). I believe it was Faulks’ intention to dig into the sub-strata of European history and explore the vital period of the early 20th century, 1918 being a hugely important watershed for Europe. It is widely believed in Britain, for example, that the spur for the inception of the welfare state, unthinkable in the 19th century, was the feeling that Britain in 1918, as Lloyd George put it, had to become a land “fit for heroes to live in” (meaning: for the returning soldiers).Another aspect of the novel is the incredible military tunnelling work that went on beneath No Man’s Land in France and Belgium (I am resisting the temptation of seeing these descriptions as a symbol of Faulks’ digging around in European history!). It is an almost incomprehensible concept: men digging miles of tunnels under the fields in order to spy on and fight each other. To the eyes of the observer nearly a century later this is an utterly absurd and futile activity – what on earth was the purpose, in ultimate terms, of this? The symbolism of the soldiers’ emergence from these tunnels at the very end of the war after the fighting has ceased, so close in the narrative to Elizabeth’s giving birth to the boy called John, is unmistakeable, if, dare I say it, a little overladen with “hidden” meaning for my taste. But I am snobbish, and Faulks wrote for a newspaper that more than anything else embraced ideals of European unity at a time when the British were still ignorant and hostile to these ideas. In my view, such ignorance was, and in some cases still is, a consequence of the fact that no fighting ever took place on British soil. Many British soldiers’ sense of isolation and alienation at the end of both wars had its roots not only in the horror that they had seen, but also in the fact that virtually no one “back home” had any idea about the nature and scale of what had really happened in the killing fields of Europe. Jeanne, the French woman who takes care of (and eventually marries) Stephen is depicted as an enormously understanding soul, and this was surely only possible because she had been so close to the events. Mainland Britain experienced hardship, but no horror. And the horror truly was unspeakable, unrepeatable. Stephen utters not a single word for two whole years after the end of the war.There is much more to this novel than meets the eye – it is more than just a gripping tale set in WW1, and I think about its scenes and implications a lot as a British citizen living in Germany and with children who are at home in both of these countries.

This was a great book, and I can totally see why it would get 5 stars. It was really well-written, it didn't feel too drawn out, or too constricted, and the imagery of war was especially evocative. The frequent descriptions of the claustrophobia of being in the tunnels, to the horror of seeing a friend's head getting blown off by a machine gun, even to the almost irrational fears Stephen has of the canary, they all felt so real and I had to stop reading at a few moments to make sure that all my limbs and body parts were still in place. It made for a harrowing, uncomfortable, but necessary read.As much as this might make me seem like a slightly cold-hearted bitch, the only thing holding me back from giving this the 5 stars it probably deserves is that I didn't feel as moved by it as much as expected. Honestly, it shocked me too but, aside from a couple of moments, this novel didn't quite connect and I, as much as I tried to, could not feel that invested in Stephen Wraysford and his life. I think part of this might be due to the addition of the later timeline (view spoiler)[in the 1970s in the last third or so of the book. I could feel myself start to feel more for Wraysford, and it felt wrenched away when we're introduced to Elizabeth and her role as his descendant. I'm not too sure what the intent was with this aspect but I wasn't the biggest fan of these sections  (hide spoiler)]. I will say that the parts that moved me were poignant and heartfelt (view spoiler)[ especially when the deaths around Stephen just felt more and more desperately sad, from Byrne, to Weir, all the way to Firebrace  (hide spoiler)]. I also began to understand the role of Stephen's dalliance with Isabelle by the 70%ish point, or wherever Jeanne makes an appearance. I think it allows us to see the contrast between his ways and his life prior to war and how impactful it was on him in its aftermath - most strongly through showing his all-consuming passion and love for Isabelle.This has made me want to read much more historical fiction, which isn't something I tend to do. I'm just having a quick look through my 'Year in Books' on here and, apart from Ivan Denisovich, which I read specifically for a class, the multiple historical romances I read which aren't exactly the most informative or accurate (as much as I love them!), and Ruta Sepety's  Salt to the Sea which I did like but didn't feel too attached to, this was comparatively a much better and more touching read (even though, as described earlier, this hasn't quite hit me in the heart with feels). I've had a quick google search of other books set in this time and, hopefully in the new year, I'll get round to reading classics like  A Farewell to Arms and  All Quiet on the Western Front. Gonna give this one a 4.5 star.

Beautifully written but very graphic content about WWI battle injuries. I was drawn into the story but found it a little too romantic for my liking. Still, the characters were interesting and the atmosphere very realistic."....the guns at last fell silent. The earth began to move. To their right a man who had lain still since the first attack, eased himself upright, then fell again when his damaged leg would not take his weight. Other single men moved, and began to come up like worms from their shellholes, limping, crawling, dragging themselves out. Within minutes the hillside was seething with the movement of the wounded as they attempted to get themselves back to their line... It was like a resurrection in a cemetery twelve miles long. Bent, agonized shapes loomed in multitudes on the churned earth, limping and dragging back to reclaim their life. It was as though the land were disgorging a generation of crippled sleepers, each one distinct but related to its twisted brothers as they teemed up from the reluctant earth.---------------------------------------To begin with he asked after the whereabouts of each missing man. After a time he saw that it would take too long. Those who had survived were not always sure whom they had seen dead. They hung their heads in exhaustion, as though every organ of their bodies was begging for release. Price began to speed the process. He hurried from one unanswered name to the next. Byrne, Hunt, Jones, Tipper, Wood, Leslie, Barnes, Studd, Richardson, Savile, Thompson, Hodgson, Birkenshaw, Llewellyn, Francis, Arkwright, Duncan, Shea, Simons, Anderson, Blum, Fairbrother. Names came pattering into the dusk, bodying out the places of their forebears, the villages and towns where the telegrams would be delivered, the houses where the blinds would be drawn, where low moans would come in the afternoon behind closed doors; and the places that had borne them, which would be like nunneries, like dead towns without their life or purpose, without the sound of fathers and their children, without young men at the factories or in the fields, with no husbands for the women, no deep sound of voices in the inns, with the children who would have been born, who would have grown and worked or painted, even governed, left ungenerated in their fathers’ shattered flesh that lay in stinking shellholes in the beet-crop soil, leaving their homes to put up only granite slabs in place of living flesh, on whose inhuman surface the moss and lichen would cast their crawling green indifference."YIKES! There is another thread that follows characters in the 1970's and, while there are some parallels to the WWI era, it was dull in comparison.

Like a few others who have put up reviews about this book on here, I’ve had to study this book for literature A-level, and ’ll be honest: the writing itself isn’t that bad. But this book includes themes that are both unnecessary to the plot and that make the main character, Steven, very unlikeable, which makes it very hard to actually enjoy 2/3 of the book, and on top of that I cared very little about the last third and the characters it concerns itself with. In the first few pages, Steven wasn’t that bad, but within the first two chapters I just began to hate him. I understand that Faulks wanted to sorta liberate the female characters in this text and bring to light their struggles within a 1910s society, but certain plot lines like Isabelle leaving her rich husband when he’s her only financial support, blatantly stating her affair to his face, and a bunch of other shite that happened with her character was so unbelievable and genuinely not likely to happen at all within that time period. Faulks failed not only in making Isabelle’s liberation arc believable, but in general somehow made the struggles of the 1910s women worse by obsessing over the violence committed against them. For starters,the stuff with Lisette? Why? Maybe a 20 year old man groping a 16 year old girl being romanticised would be believable and somewhat overlooked in an actual 1910s text, but Faulks as a writer from the 90s had no actual reason to put that in and it served no purpose to the plot. What really pissed me off after that was how Steven decided to tell Isabelle, Lisette’s step-mother, and it’s described as arousing her??? The overall intimate parts were terrible and even though they were written to liberate Isabelle etc they just did the opposite. I’d rather just have read an actual 1910s text that excluded the terrible and weird ass sex parts. Fgs steven has an oedipus complex and he’s also super forceful on Isabelle, not uncommon for the time period but the way it is romanticised by the author makes it super weird. Also the threatening a prostitute with a knife was super unnecessary. Maybe I’m just bias because I hated Steven, but the overall plot was underwhelming too and Faulks’ writing didn’t make up for all the weird shit he put in there.

Birdsong is a novel consisting of several arcs that alternate between the passionate tryst of Stephen Wraysford and Isabella Fourmentier, the inhumane, destructive spoils of World War I, and a woman whose curiosity is piqued after reading an article about the anniversary of the Armistice. Stephen encounters Isabella during his tenure at her husband's house. The other invited guests display gross, ostentatious personas that he strongly dislikes. Stephen is described as a dispassionate character, whose distant facade conceals a barely suppressed emotional volatility. Isabella, an elegant trophy housewife possessing a quietly willful streak, is equally attracted to him, but is frightened by what their encounter beholds. Still, they carry on with their affair, and finally elope, causing a social uproar. Isabella soon discovers that she's pregnant, has second thoughts, and secretly returns to her sister's house. Stephen doesn't hear from her again, until much later, when he meets her sister Jeanne by accident. In the meantime, Stephen is crushed by Isabella's abrupt departure. After enrolling into the army during World War I, he finds his emotional and physical fortitude pushed to the extremes. The war scenes are described too well to a disturbing extent. The soldiers end up becoming grotesque playthings of flesh, as wave after wave of them are killed. The remaining soldiers have to relive the horror of waking up every day to an uncertain fate. As the soldiers forge strong bonds over battles, women and the brief respites of rest, they are aware of how laughingly tenuous these relations are. Even when they return to their homes, they find themselves isolated by their unwilling burden, their minds suspended in the fight-or-die response of war, tired beyond breaking point. The ones that do survive harden themselves emotionally to survive the physical and emotional onslaught, but this repression inevitably becomes traumatic. Brennan, a WWI veteran, lives out much of his entire life incoherent, his mind forever frozen in the early 1910s'. This is my first Faulks novel and it's written in an obsessively microscopic, yet curiously detached manner. I'm not yet sure how to feel about this, although it's a solid work on its own merits. The nearest feeling I could come to is a fascination?

This book was so promising at first - extramarital passion in an early 1900s French village? Yes please! But after Part I (of VII) it very quickly and completely became a war novel. There are war novels and then there are novels that use war as a setting to explore and amplify other themes. This is the former, with most of the book detailing gruesome WWI trench warfare. It also has moving depictions of the psychological effects of war. I just don’t happen to want to read about it. That’s not the book’s failure. A more objective miss for me was something that I often complain about - the contrived use of alternating past/present storylines. My issue with this device is that, instead of two equally developed stories, one (usually the present-day storyline) inevitably is a throwaway to help move along the past story. That proved to be the case here. The bulk of this story takes place before and during WWI with protagonist Stephen, interspersed with flash-forward sections revolving around his granddaughter. These modern-day (well, circa 1978) interruptions felt unnecessarily forced and lacked real character development. For example, we never got a good sense of Elizabeth or why she suddenly feels a compulsion to learn about her grandfather and his time in the war. Moreover, why did she call up random senile old men who possibly served with Stephen when her own mother, with whom she appears rather close, had all relevant information that she easily shared with her over one pleasant lunch and by digging out old journals from the attic? The story would have been better served without the Elizabeth modern-day portions. Then Faulks could have used the freed up pages to better develop some characters who danced around the main frame but never materialized as real or complex, e.g., Jack Firebrace or Jeanne. On the plus side, this book had a couple of the steamiest scenes I’ve seen outside of a romance novel. Unfortunately, the war parts were equally vivid and significantly more plentiful. 3.5 stars

Definitely took a great deal of time with this one! I'm contemplating whether this would be a 3 or 4 stars for me. Let's leave it there. What I loved : Well firstly, picked it up because of Ben Barnes❤️ I must say that This book was not like any other war novels that I have read. This was actually about the horrors of war. Their lives, the bombardment, the shellfire, their friends, family, their uniforms soaked wih lice, their tea from petrol drums. God! I'm sure i had dreams about those trenches and dugouts and tunnels. It was so well written and loved all the characters. I loved especially of how raw the WORLD WAR 1 was described and also the thoughts of those soilders. About how they can never be normal or lead a normal life. About how back home nobody knows about how the war was about the lives of these soilders and all the cruel things they face every single day and how they a traumatised by the things they see that happened to their friends. How nobody will ever know. And what actually kept these men going all those years with their life sucked out of them. God! Got quite heavy there at a time. Told in different timeframe with 3 generations with heartbreaking stories of erotic love, passion friendships i think this was a great book. What I didn't like: The narration kept losing the main characters. The characters that we were getting to know and caring for. At one point there were no main characters. There was only war. I actually found that Historical fiction is my new favourite genre! Cannot wait to read more! And cannot wait to read Sebastian Faulks's Engleby and his other books.

I've been meaning to start posting on here for a while, and Birdsong is a great place to start.This is by no means a perfect novel; the "flash forward" sections for example are a little bit awkward. But I don't think I have ever read a more moving account of life on the battlefield.Very early sections of the novel reminded me of Jane Austen. There's something about the way Faulks sets up the domestic life in Amiens, France in 1910. Like Austen, he shows how individual personalities and social station can influence behavior, in a way that is illuminating and entertaining. As the action heated up in the first section, the passion and romance felt like Ian McEwan's Atonement. (Lots of reviews of this book mention McEwan.) But that's just the beginning. The war scenes make this novel into one I would recommend not just to my literary-minded friends, but to anyone. Faulks is able to give dignity and grace to the individuals who experienced and perpetrated some of the most horrific acts of war on the planet. There's a scene in the novel that takes place on the first day of the Battle of the Somme. On a hill above the battle a group of characters view the carnage below, and each witness is fundamentally changed by the experience. I think maybe that's the best way to describe this novel. It fundamentally changed my understanding of the experience of war. Not sure if I can conjure up any higher praise than that.Give it a read.

Birdsong deals well with themes of war, trauma, how to integrate generations and remember historic traumas, the passing on of history and how it matters, love and selfhood. It's hard to know what to say about this book, in any case, it's all been said already. I was hesitant to make a judgment on it due to a) my complete lack of knowledge of WWI and b) my lack of knowledge of what those who went through the war would have thought about the book. Some light research has reassured me of the accuracy of the depictions and the realistic nature of the book & now I can let myself truly feel the value and impact of the writing. I teared up and felt dizzy at moments reading the graphic scenes of this novel, the writing really is extraordinarily vivid and touching. I had to remind myself throughout that this was not WW2, fictions and films and plays of which I'd grown up with, but something totally separate and worthy of artistic probing its in its own right. The first part could have been shorter and the book could have dove into the war sooner I think, once that happened I was gripped. Then again, I don't feel confident saying any part of this book was unnecessary or less important than the war scenes even if it feels that way, because all of it works together to make it the book that it is with the impact that it is. This book will stay with me and I understand why it's so renowned.

The heart-rending story of a man caught up in The Great War, Birdsong is a reminder that no one can truly comprehend what it is like to be on the front lines except the men who are there experiencing and participating in the horror. No history book, no movie will ever truly capture that or be able to justify man's inhumanity to man in any conflict. Faulks does a superb job of taking us from the easy, carefree, pre-war days in France to the stinking battlefields in the same country a few years later. His graphic, straight-forward descriptions left me grasping for answers, searching for reasons, wondering, like the soldiers he described, what it was all for. Perhaps Elizabeth Benson sums it up best in the story, when she is overcome by a simple war memorial and says, "Nobody told me. My God, nobody told me." (My main issue with the book and the reason I didn't rate it higher was the two affairs that were the love stories in the past and the present.) Favorite quotes: "No one in England knows what this is like. If they could see the way these men live they would not believe their eyes. This is not a war, this is an exploration of how far men can be degraded." - Stephen Wraysford "It is surprising what you can learn if you just spend some time reading." - Bob"Where there is real love between people, as there was between all of us, then the details don't matter. Love is more important than the flesh-and-blood facts of who gave birth to whom." - Francoise

Well. I had been meaning to read this for a while, as was aware that it was considered to be modern classic, and occasionally I feel the need to educate myself. However, I discovered a rather obvious typo second sentence in - which could have been a sign...Whilst I have to admit to finding the book interesting from a historical aspect - I'm assuming it was well researched! - I found the overall shape of it to be turgid, meandering with little reason and the characters were all hugely unlikeable so that I really didn't care too much about what happened to any of them. The much revered love story between the two main characters of the beginning, was less to do with love and far more to do with lust, as was the rather pathetic relationship between Elizabeth and her lover. The descriptions of the horrendous conditions of the trenches were vivid and could be gripping and there was some emotional purchase in the decline of the men afterwards, but I was left wondering whether the book was meant to be about the horrors of war, the too quick to forgetfulness of human kind, or????? On the whole, I thought the book to be too much of a non-coherent mish mash of torrid lust story, a la Mills and Boon, historical documentary and family epic.

My copy of this book has the cooler cover of the naked man curled with hands around knees. I have heard that this was such a tremendous book, that I may have unrealistically set my expectations so high that no novel could meet them. Ultimately, I thought this was just okay. It had several different appealing parts, but the whole left me unfulfilled and unimpressed. Faulks does several things well or appealingly. He successfully recreates a forbidden love affair in pre- WW1 France. He pulls off sex scenes without sounding ridiculous -no small writerly feat. They are interesting and have the ring of truth about them. The depiction of World War one battle and the bureaucratic grind of trench warfare, especially the tunneling or mining crews was also nonpareil. They had a claustrophobic effect that also somehow echoed and underscored the overwhelming feeling of the constant fear of death. Again an excellent part of a somehow dissatisfying whole. The rendering of the scenes of the 70's, as a central character tries to reconnect with her grandfather's history during World War One, were less engaging, but again appeal as a masterly writer's effect. Glad I read it, and I hope I haven't scared anyone off. Faulks is a writer to pay attention to.

In the introduction to my 20th anniversary edition of this, Faulks credits himself with being the only English writer of the 1990s to focus on WWI, but we should certainly credit Pat Barker as well.A long book, it starts a few years before the war - Stephen Wraysford, the central character is an Englishman who has more or less expatriated himself to France and had a scandalous affair in a small town with a married woman. The war starts and he joins the British army, rising to be a lieutenant despite his lack of quite the proper military mindset, though the uncertainty of purpose felt by everyone as the carnage dragged on is no surprise. There are many other characters, representing various walks of life, social classes and belief systems.About halfway through, a subplot is introduced; Wraysford's granddaughter, a successful single adult in 1978 becomes very interested in her family history. She finally pieces together a version of the story with the big family secret that has scarcely been let out in the earlier part of the narrative. Clever constructed with appealingly complex characters.

I have wanted to read this book for a while and remember seeing some of the BBC adaptation a few years ago.Sebastian Faulks does a good job writing a novel about The First World War in France The book starts a few years before the war when the young Stephen Wraysford goes to Amiens to work and live with a French family which causes tension amongst the family. Years later he is fighting in the war and you go through the war with him and a tunneller called Jack which adds another dimension. I enjoyed the beginning part especially. I remembered most of this first section from the BBC adaptation but still loved the characters and the writing. I also loved the part set in the 70s but sometimes found the war era sections a bit intense! Faulks writes well about the brutality of the war as well as marriage, relationships and family but sometimes it could become battle after battle which is probably why I loved the more character based parts. The writing was pretty good but having read other books by him you can tell it was one of his earliest works and that he was still finding his style. A good novel about The First World War with some moving and poignant moments but I personally preferred The girl at the lion d'or.

The extent of the novel’s ambition cannot be immediately appreciated or even understood, but is, instead, slowly unraveled to become more and more remarkable as the narrative progresses. The story’s sinuous trajectory and gripping context come to life with such vibrancy that is at times hard to believe it is mere fiction. It manages to bring together such seemingly contradictory stories, of tender passion and heinous war, to give the entire narrative an intensity only heightened by Faulks thrilling descriptive prose. He doesn't abstain from raw and explicit depictions which are, ultimately, what make his book so hauntingly great as it manages to depict with such realism the atrocities of the first World War whilst creating such a uniquely intimate atmosphere. It is difficult not to be captivated by Birdsong’s melancholic journey through time, passed some of the most abominable moments of the past century.

Harrowing. Horrific. Heart-rending. This is a powerful story spanning three generations, starting in 1910 with an illicit love affair between a young Englishman and an older, married Frenchwoman. Moving forward a few years, we find our protagonist immersed in the trenches of WWI, the reality of which is unflinchingly portrayed. Nothing is left to the imagination, revealing the shocking futility of war and the sheer carnage that is the result. The filth, the claustrophobia, the mud, the lice, the brutality, the camaraderie, the despair, the exhaustion, the fear, the hope, the uncertainty; all are captured brilliantly. Then, 60 years later, we meet the granddaughter who embarks on a quest to learn more about a grandfather about whom she knows very little. Through her discoveries, threads of his pre and post-war life are tied together. One of those books that stays with you long after closing it.

Birdsong had been sitting on my shelf for he longest time. Honestly. I am happy to report it will now be moved to my 'read' pile. It is subtle, it is beautiful, it is painful. The characters are carved with such tiny detail; one of my favourite things ever. It is heavy but I was never bored. Describing so much, including the futility and helplessness of war, the importance and strength of friendships, seeking whatever solace and comfort we can find. It was magnificent; I don't think I've sunk into pages about WW1 as much as I did here. It's a big read at over 500 pages; I really enjoyed taking chunks out of it whilst I was off work.  "This is not a war, this is an exploration of how far men can be degraded. I am deeply curious to see how much further it can be taken; I want to know. I believe that it has barely started."________________________________________

This book shows the horror of life in the trenches for the allied soldiers in World War I better than any book I have ever read. It also vividly details the life and work of the miners whose job was to dig tunnels for espionage or attacking purposes. It follows Stephen as he progresses through the war and how the constant array of death changes his character. There is a modern element that lacks the intensity and compelling nature of the war narrative. The change in writing is very noticable. I wonder if the writer was making a statement about the late 1970s or perhaps was providing the reader with relief from the amazing intensity of the war. Throughout the war, the birds sing. Each song a harbinger that something is coming. One of the best novels of war ever.

I seem to be exposed to a lot of WWI history lately. I recently read All Quiet on the Western Front, watched the movie 1917 and now finished Birdsong. I agree with my sister that some of the story was frustrating but overall, I believe this book will stick with me for a long time. The author does an amazing job writing about trench warfare and of the causes of shell shock. I felt hints of Joesph Conrad’s book, Heart of Darkness, on how the mind twists with hallucinations and despair and tries to make sense of senseless things. How love and passion can feel differently within the same relationship. This was on the UK’s list of the top 100 books one must read and I can see why. I’m glad I read it.

This took me some time to get into, not because it was bad, but because it was just so heavy. I’m starting to love historical fiction a lot more nowadays, and the beautiful writing in Birdsong reminded me why. It’s absolutely gut-wrenching reading about the horrors of war, but Sebastian Faulks has done a great job at expressing it. I have to say that I didn’t particularly enjoy the 1979 Elizabeth storyline - she seemed quite inconsiderate about things like PTSD and trauma in this quest she went on to find out more about her grandfather, so I wasn’t particularly fond of her. The 1917 storyline was great though. 4 stars!

I first read this book back in the nineties and kept my original copy as I knew that I would eventually read it again. The book takes you from pre-war France in the early 1900’s to the trenches of the First World War and to 1970’s London. We have all heard of the horrors of the First World War and the dreadful conditions men had to endure in the trenches and within the endless tunnels they dug to thwart the enemy.The descriptions in this book are horrifying and sometimes hard to read. Mud, rats, rotting bodies that couldn’t be retrieved from the barbed wire of the battlefield. Descriptions such as the strategic practice of officers reading out the names of the deserters executed to the foot soldiers the night before men were told they were going ‘over the top’ is chilling. Social class and rank was a huge determinant in the odds of survival. Despite the horror of the book there is a thread of hope and love throughout. This is masterful writing and highly recommended.

Birdsong is a beautifully sentimental novel about war, love, family, and trauma. It is incredibly written, and despite its slow pacing, I finished it in less than two days. It was emotional, and gripping, and raw, and absolutely devastating. Some parts did suffer from the slow pacing where the plot wasn't as strong, but even during these moments, the tone and the characters were developed. The timeline jumps often felt disjointed, but it wraps up very nicely, and ultimately, I liked the way it all came together. It's not a perfect novel, but it's undoubtedly a good one.

I want to give this all the stars, 5 don't seem to cover the love I have for this book. First of all I am in awe of Faulks's writing in general - beautifully crafted sentences of which almost all are quotable. The characters are real, raw and sometimes unpredictable. The story is heartbreaking, unforgettable and sadly very realistic. I believe this should be one of the classics of the 20th century and urge everyone to read it as well, and teach it to students.

This was a moving book - the parts set in the war were particularly hard-hitting and at times horrifying. It really brought to life the feeling of the trenches. The love story between Stephen and Isabelle really served as a stark contrast with the war that followed it. Unfortunately, for me the weakest parts were those set in the 70s with Elizabeth - I didn't warm to her character sadly. Overall a good read.

Don't think I've read another book with such detail of someone fighting from forefront of a war. Heartbreaking. There are many minor characters and many deaths. One instant they are there - talking, sharing a joke, anxious, sad - and next instant they are gone forever...The usual response when you read on and on about collective pain is a kind of numbness but here somehow the author still manages to evoke sorrow with every account.

WWI has been so overshadowed by the later war that the horrific reality of trench warfare seems unthinkable. I never knew what sappers did, that beneath no man's land they were digging many other tunnels to undermine enemy trenches. By the end of the war, the main character is so damaged that his daughter remembers he didn't speak for 2 years.There is a love story also, not at all a conventional one. The modern counter narrative is not nearly as compelling as the earlier story.

Way too long - the story would have been better (IMHO) if there was less specific sexual descriptions and if the war descriptions were less lengthy -- Pretty much skimmed thru those parts. Enjoyed the switch to the 1970s when the young lady was trying to connect her life with what happened in WWI.

Once I got into the book I couldn't put it down. WWI Was supposed to be the war to end all wars but even the horrors of the trench warfare, the "no mans land" the loss of life and devastation of WWI didn't stop WWII from happening. If the generation of WWII is considered the "greatest generation" what can the generation of WWI be. What would the world be if we didn't lose so many to war, any war. Yes there was a love story but more than that there was a story of strength of will and will to live that surprised even the main character.

A multi-generational war novel that spans the years from 1917 to the late 1970s. The main focus is WWI and the horrors of trench-warfare. The incredible detail presented here is both harrowing and fascinating, counterbalanced by a sweeping love story. Very well-written and researched. My first Faulks.

The only reason I am giving this book 2 stars instead of one, is for the vividly written and realistic portrayal of the horrors of the trenches during WWI. That part of the book was quite riveting but the rest was just superfluous romantic, porn "love scenes" which I found quite misogynistic. Don't understand how they can even compare this to Hemingway. My opinion: don't bother.

The programme of events commemorating the centenary of World War 1 has triggered interest and heightened awareness of what is often referred to as “the forgotten war”, and we all wish to extend our appreciation of such momentous events. “Birdsong” (1993) is, of course, a work of fiction, but it is the product of extensive, detailed and original research. Faulks immersed himself in the time and the events that characterise it. In so doing he has been able to bring insights that seem authentic to a story line that compares and contrasts the vagaries of human nature when confronted with horror. Above all it gives you a sense of what it must have felt like to fight in the trenches.Some of our group had read Birdsong some time ago and had re-read the book in order to refresh their memory. They all found added benefit in the second reading, uncovering depth in the characters and their contemplations, and wider themes in the book.There were differing views of the “time shifts” otherwise described as “jump cuts”. Some thought it worked brilliantly, drawing out the contrast between untroubled pre-war life, the wretchedness of war itself and the transition to post war reality, and embodying his wider themes about time and the generations. Others thought the time shifts “a bit clunky” and “irritating”, particularly the shift to the 1970’s.There was a general view that the first part of the book that deals with Stephen’s life in Amiens, staying with the Azaire family and having a passionate affair with his host's wife Isabelle, was a bit too long. One person was tempted to stop reading at this stage; however, all were sufficiently encouraged by the description of the steamy sex to carry on reading.The jump from peacetime Amiens to the Western Front in 1916 was a surprise and a shock to all, with the stark contrast between the love affair in the peaceful countryside of northern France and the horrors of the Somme. This narrative technique worked well throughout the book, and was greatly appreciated by all.It was mentioned that Faulks deliberately imitated cinematic narrative devices, “moving from unbearable close ups to a view on a long lens and a very wide shot”. This thread permeates all parts of the novel, and was particularly effective when deployed in linking time, building characters and in dealing with themes such as life and death.Death is an ever-present theme. The scale and arbitrariness of death, and the impact on individuals and their families and comrades are topics that are especially well portrayed. The impression is given of fleeting contact with individuals, insights into their lives followed by descriptions of their deaths, sometimes casual and sometimes in graphic detail. It was suggested that the death of comrades in some way helped to secure a closer bond between those remaining and to unite them in a common cause.The group admired Faulks’ descriptive powers in relation to the scale and nature of death:“bodies were starting to pile and clog the progress”; “explosives can reduce men to particles so small that only the wind carried them - men simply go missing”.Stephen’s granddaughter, Elizabeth Benson, on visiting a cemetery near Bapaume in the Somme, felt that “on every surface of every column as far as her eye could see there were names teeming, reeling, over surfaces of yards, of hundreds of yards, over furlongs of stone”.One of our company particularly liked Stephen speaking to Gray regarding the attack on Beaumont Hammel “I looked in your eyes and there was perfect blankness”, and following the attack as darkness fell the movement of the wounded was described as “It was like a resurrection in a cemetery 12 miles long”.Most of the group agreed that the strongest and most memorable sections in the book for them were those concerning the 1st day of the Somme offensive and those describing the underground warfare. The seduction of Isabelle in Amiens was also admired, but the reasons for the end of the affair remained a bit of a mystery.There were mixed views on the sections dealing with the 1970’s. Some considered them a bit contrived, particularly the coded diaries, while others thought them well structured and entirely appropriate given their purpose to suggest that time heals, that hope arises out of despair and that life goes on.The group was surprised to learn that Faulks had written the book in only 6 months. It was his fourth novel and by far the most successful. It was the unanimous view of the group that “Birdsong” is a great modern novel….This is an extract from a Monthly Book Group review at: https://monthlybookgroup.wordpress.com/ Our reviews are also to be found at http://monthlybookgroup.blogspot.co.uk/

“This is not a war, this is an exploration of how far man can be degraded.”I didn’t want to write this review. Some books just hurt too much, touch at places which go beyond the reach of words. But I was a bit agitated today, and writing kindda helps me calm down. So here I am. Most of it might just come out as lot of blabbering, so bear with me please. “They were in their own view a formidable group of men. No inferno would now melt them, no storm destroy, because they had seen the worst and they had survived.”As I started reading, I was promised a love story, not without its fair share of heart ache and falsehood though, but I was soon thrown into war. I felt trapped, because, no matter how many aches are a part of a love story, it is never as difficult to absorb as a war story. Not that I didn’t know it was coming, but no matter what you do, you can never prepare yourself for the blow that is headed your way. “They had seen things no human eyes had looked on before, and they hadn’t turned their gaze away.”Have you ever felt helpless because you have loved and lost? How would you feel if you know you have a child but for years you were unaware of her existence? That feeling of helplessness is so gut wrenching and soul thrashing. Isn’t it? Have you ever suffered identity crisis? When you have no soul in the world whom you can call your family or friend. You feel utterly lost? Don’t you?“I saw the great void in your soul, and you saw mine.” But life is full of tragedies that are far worse than a mere heart break at the loss of a loved one. And hence we are acquainted with the survivor’s guilt our protagonist suffered after coming out alive of a war that completely put him out of touch with reality, and transformed him from the person he used to be before it. “They were frightening to the civilians because they had evolved into passive beings whose only aim was to endure.”Ironically suffering was not for those who died. Because most of them didn’t suffer. Their souls left their bodies within seconds. It only crept up to those who were left behind. Left behind to see once living breathing humans now turned into scattered pieces of meat and pools of blood. The gory images of human brains splashed around, half face men, where rest of the face had been blown up by splinters of shells, one human body over another piling up like rotten meat or merely shattered into so many pieces that it was hard to differentiate between dust and human. But nothing will shock you while you are reading it. Because till the time you finish reading it up, you would become as numb and insensible to pain as the protagonist. You will feel lost, but nothing like Stephen, who couldn’t utter a single word for two years. Because he had already lost connection with the so called normal life, a life he didn’t recognise any longer, after facing four years of grotesque war imagery where men died left and right but he kept surviving because he was just that lucky. But was he really? “But it’s not the details of life I’ve lost. It’s the reality itself.”As Faulks help us walk through all the suffering, it felt like I could see it all through the eyes of a person who might have seen it himself, endure it through a heart which has the pain pierced through his own. For that how captivating the prose of this book is. There are no big soliloquies uttered in pain, there are no long paragraphs describing human suffering. It is just small sentences here and there, which would leave you stunned for few seconds, before you could gather enough courage to read the next line. “Something had been buried that was not dead yet.”

Birdsong is a 1993 novel by Sebastian Faulks, about Stephen Wraysford, an orphan cum clothmerchant cum homewrecker cum infantry officer perpetually stationed in the line alongside a tunnelling corps. Focuses primarily on the tunnelling corps and their activities, with the obligatory couple of trips ‘over the top’ for Wraysford.I was initially disposed to like this book. The preface impressed me with Faulks’ thoughtfulness about his characters and how the story would set up point and counterpoint between the characters and time periods. There was also some interesting content in terms of the section set in Amiens before the war, and particularly around the tunnelling company’s activities.However, despite this good start, I didn’t particularly enjoy Birdsong. Ultimately I think I enjoyed this book so little because it was fundamentally character-driven, with several wishy-washy plots that meandered around and ended when the novel ended, not because they’d found their natural conclusion. The plotline of Wraysford’s granddaughter discovering his diaries in 1978 was particularly weak (she read like a throwaway character, and the plot relied on melodrama).It probably isn’t fair of me to hang my criticism on this point, since it is partly an issue of taste not quality; I am a genre reader consuming everything produced about an era which seems primarily to inspire ‘literary’ writers concerned with character study, c.f. Pat Barker’s Regeneration. I think more recent writers have taken their cue from the memoirists such as Robert Graves and Vera Brittain in terms of the type of story and style of narrative used - hence all those shell-shocked officer heroes. But whereas Graves, Brittain, Sassoon, Remarque, etc, were drawing from life, Faulks and Barker draw from a caricature of life based largely on a monochrome myth of WWI and life in the trenches. I don’t doubt Faulks’ research, or the authenticity of what he writes, but Birdsong offered me nothing that other authors hadn’t done earlier, and better.One thing that particularly irritated me was the relentless, one-eyed proselytising about the Horror of War. Some of this is to be expected, but it is constant. Wraysford, according to the preface, was supposed to be created as a man with the characteristics that would allow him to get through the war more-or-less intact. Although Wraysford ‘talks the talk’ on this, his actions show him as falling into the aforementioned standard shellshocked officer type. Again, I am not objecting to the realism; I just don’t think Birdsong offers anything that other authors haven’t done better.There is also nothing wrong with preaching the Horror of War. But whereas Wilfred Owen or Erich Maria Remarque show it to us, Faulks tells us all about it, then tells us how we should feel about it. For example, upon seeing the Thiepval memorial to the missing of the Somme, Wraysford’s granddaughter sinks to her knees and whispers, ‘why did no-one ever tell us?’.Ultimately, to anyone thinking of reading this, I would suggest they read Robert Graves’ Good-bye to All That instead. Almost the same story, but without all the hand-wringing.

Riveting and compelling. This literary tour de force is a powerful read in the sense that you find yourself stopping to catch your breath and containing all the overwhelming emotions the magnificent tapestry of words evoke. Faulks is a magnificent storyteller, narrating not just the atrocities of war and the flaws of humanity in the face of violence but as a whole creates a story that resonates hope amidst the horrors, an enduring kindness amidst the cruelties of man, and new beginnings bridged by future generations which know no bloodshed became an enduring force for survival. A poignant account of war spoken against the backdrop of the essence of humanity- a test of faith among the believers, and a solace and purpose for those who found no refuge in living. It raises the questions to what extent can war push soldiers further against the core of humanity and integrity and if there is a ceiling, or if that ceiling continues to go higher as war demands them to become cold-blooded killing machines automatically programmed to hate. In the face of it all, this novel paints a picture where hate is not the most extreme lengths a person stripped of their humanity can go, but that of becoming a person whose only emotion shows indifference and submission to nothingness.  At the same time it expresses a continuous and unwavering belief in the inherent goodness of man, as personified by Jack and Margaret Firebrace in the story. While the story also highlights the star-crossed love affair of Stephen and Isabelle, I believe that what made this book special was Jack Firebrace's devotion to his son and wife.

What a fantastic novel. I freely admit that I only picked this up because I found the recent PBS miniseries based on the book to be compulsively watchable and hoped that the source material would be half as good. Turns out, it was in many ways considerably better and certainly more intense. The book is subtitled “A novel of love and war” and that’s how I think I’ll divide my thoughts on it. It is initially and perhaps most importantly a love story. Wraysford and Isabelle’s affair is as passionate as it is brief and Faulks writes it with such conviction that you believe it implicitly. He manages to run the gamut from the most restrained suggestion to the frankly explicit while retaining a gorgeous, literary style. It’s funny to me how simple and natural it is to cheer for adultery in so many great novels when it makes me feel so sick in real life. Isabelle’s husband is probably too conveniently and perfectly awful, but it does save me from uncomfortable moral qualms about their behavior. And while they have their moment in the sun, this isn’t a paperback romance novel, so things go wrong and Wraysford is left devastated and confused. Which brings us to the war part of the story. I feel that I can’t be alone in saying that the First World War seems to be routinely glossed over in every history course I’ve ever taken, in favor of the glamour and popularity of WWII. I wonder if it might be because even at a distance of nearly a hundred years, the utter waste of it all is just too jarring and incomprehensible to really dwell on. There don’t seem to be any tidy moral lessons or inspirational moment as abound with WWII; there was only the carnage of mechanized warfare fought with foolish, untenable strategies of an earlier time. I loved this story for bringing it alive in blood and dirt and horror soaked reality. The author’s descriptions of the trenches and the endless, soul-crushing terror of the front lines are the best I’ve ever read on the subject. The most fascinating thing was the way the men became numbed to the sight of constant, cheap, and horrifyingly gruesome death. The psychological truama of it all is impossible to get one’s mind around. They all dealt with it differently - Weir drank his nerves and anger into submission, Grey hid behind a sort of patriotic blindness, Firebrace clung precariously to faith and family, but Wraysford was the most interesting. He simply endured. There was his grim curiosity about seeing the war through, if only to see how much further the preverseness and depravity of the war could be taken. There was his fading remembrance of Isabelle and the more immediate, though less passionate, love of Jeanne. Most of all, though, was the elemental desire to simply keep on living even though he didn’t know why or what for. This was so very, very good. The writing is beautiful, the romance is exciting, and the war is devastating - it has it all. I’d very much recommend it.

Usually I read books before watch movies of a same story. This time is the other way around.
