Stephen Wraysford, the main character became so full and vivid and human as the war went on. Faulks kept saying he was strange, and I know Faulks didn't mean he was strange strange. His strangeness only enhanced the deep, emotional, intense affection he had buried in his heart. As he told Jack, "I think she (Isabelle) was my own flesh and blood. I truly believe she was." It was heart-breaking to see the pain he had hidden and suffered, and the despair in his being. The despair.Stephen's strangeness is unique, is almost profound, no, it is profound. That's why we love him. Eddie Redmayne played him so well in the TV shows, his rather distant gaze, the ready-to-disappearing grin... For a long time, I believed Eddie Redmayne was Stephen Wraysford, yet toward the end, I saw the full Stephen, with some gray hair, tall, lean, and deeper silence.I am so happy Stephen met Jeanne, and Jeanne loved him and was married to him. I am not so happy Stephen only lived a short life. But that's the cruelty of wars, no one can elaborate it and make it less cruel and grim.I have never read any books that describe war as detailed and horrific as this one did, but I believe it, I believe WWI was just like that if not worse. I can't believe how much one could endure. Stephen and Jack were stuck underground in the tunnel for days, Stephen miraculously survived. Only hope and love could have made him last that long, yet he was exhausted, "his body and his mind were tired beyond speech and beyond repair, but nothing could check the low exultation of his soul."I had waited for Jack to say that line in the TV show before he died: "Nothing more, sir. To love and to be loved". But it never appeared in the book, I guess it was added in by the screenplay writer, which matches Faulks' style perfectly.The TV series left out the modern life in England entirely, which I thought necessary. I didn't see any point of Elizabeth's existence until the very end when she gave birth to a son, the dramatic childbirth, and when she said, "I know. It's...John." I was weeping.I am not sure why the boy's name is not Stephen but John. To memorize Jack's son? To fulfill Stephen's promise to Jack?I don't know if Faulks was emotionally drained after he finished this book, I was after I read it. I like the poem he used at the title page by Tagore:"When I go from hence, let this be my parting word, that what I have seen is unsurpassable."It is unprecedented and unrepeatable, isn't it? I think so, at least this very moment.

Birdsong chiefly follows the life of Stephen Wraysford, first as an English expatriot living in France and then in his subsequent struggle through the brutality of the Western Front 1916-18. Wraysford's life is viewed through several shifting perspectives: the men under his command, his granddaughter investigating her family history from 1978 London, and of course from his own inner narrative.At first I found the sudden narrative shifts a little disconcerting, but once I was able to locate Wraysford in each new context I found the plot was actually quite tightly written and always pulling the reader to discover more of Wraysford's life. Birdsong makes for an intense, oftentimes harrowing, read. I'm reasonably well versed in WWI history, but I was still quite shocked in parts by the sheer degradation of human life that Faulks depicts. This novel is a perfect example of how narrative can be far more effective at conveying history than mere statistics and bald facts.There's a detailed development of themes here, too. Like most art forms concerned with war there's meditations on life and death and how brutality of war renders life utterly meaningless. There is also quite a bit of emphasis on the disjunction between the experiences of soldiers and civilians and how difficult it was for the former to resume the life of the latter. But what I really liked was that Faulks (if imperfectly) tries to steer the reader towards some kind of reconciliation of the horrors of events like the opening day of the Battle of the Somme, with somekind fo hope for humanity. As Wraysford searches for a reason to go on surviving machine guns and bombardments, Faulks is also trying to find a way in which he and the reader can understand the history of WWI and not be consumed in an existential vacuum. I think whether he succeeds is probably a very personal matter of interpretation, but I had sympathy with his depiction of the ongoing, cyclic flow of humanity and the way the modern world sort of carries the torch for our ancestors.This was one of the most poignant and touching novels I've read in a long while, and despite the bleakness of the subject matter, there is something very satisfying about the way Faulks closes the circle and concludes his story. I would recommend it to any reader, particularly those with an interest in WWI or historical fiction, but caveat that you might need a strong stomach to make it through.

well, wow. I can't say much about this book that hasn't already been said by hundreds of reviewers here and on Amazon. It is extremely rare for me to give a book five stars, but while this novel isn't perfect, it deserves them. I'm going to say something anyway, but you can ignore it -- just beg, borrow, or buy a copy of this book and read it. Why on earth it didn't win, or even get shortlisted for, the Booker prize I'll never know.It starts out as a defiantly 19th-century novel, reminiscent of Flaubert. No plunging the reader into the action or attempting to arouse curiosity, the first page is a description of a dull suburban street in Amiens! This first section describes the passionate affair between lonely Englishman Stephen Wraysford and the wife of his French host, a few years before the First World War. Faulks' writing is so vivid and sensual that this is utterly compelling despite the fact that "nothing much happens".We then skip ahead to the war, and much of the book is taken up with s brutally realistic description of trench warfare. Sometimes I felt Faulks went a bit far with his no-holds-barred descriptions of dragging decomposing bodies out of shellholes, seeing men with their brains dribbling out of their eye sockets -- but it's above all about the reaction of Stephen and other soldiers to extreme stress, as well as a testimony to the appalling inhumanity/insanity of which human beings are capable. Yes, there have been other books and memoirs written about this, but this moved and angered me more than any book since Vera Brittain's Testament of Youth.This novel is about characters, not plot -- Stephen is a real person, with real thoughts and feelings, real flaws, and you are completely absorbed into his experiences. The description of the attack on the Somme, and all of the last 100 pages, are compelling -- you can barely breathe as you read.Inevitably the 1978 interludes with his granddaughter Elizabeth finding his notebooks and discovering more about him were less successful. I couldn't believe that Elizabeth could be so ignorant about this war and of course her daily dilemmas were a lot less interesting. But the resolution in the final chapter rounded off the story touchingly. And it is one of those books where you immediately turn back to the beginning.

The start of this book, in which Stephen is a guest in Isabelle's house, did not immediately grip me and I found it slow going. I did not enjoy the explicit scenes between him and Isabelle's, although they seemed better drawn and less gratuitous than is usually the case. I found that I enjoyed the book far more after the change of narrative to the Great War. This, I found very moving and beautifully sketched - it truly brought the realities and horrors of the war to life for me. I was less interested in Elizabeth's life, but in some ways her narrative served to heighten the differences between the normal civilian life so many men had fought for, and their lives and deaths while fighting it.The account of their first attack was terrible: the fake assurances made to the men and the ludicrous tactics adopted (such as attacking in daylight). Worst was the relentless march of men trudging on only to be gunned down before they had barely left their trenches - only to be followed again and again by waves of men knowing the fate of those before them but doomed to step forwards into death nonetheless. The role of the sappers was new to me, and the tunnels so vividly depicted that I felt quite claustrophobic just listening to it. The eventual rescue of Stephen by German soldiers was a relief, but seemed a little too pat; every time something happened it was hard to take it completely seriously because it never seemed that the main character would actually die. His most unlikely rescue coinciding exactly with the armistice was symbolic, but too coincidental for my liking. Overall, a book that had me thinking deeply and awakened in me an interest in that period of history. I now know much more about the events of the First World War than before reading this book, and am keener to learn more. Since I have read Charlotte Grey and The Girl at the Lion d'Or, this completes the trilogy for me, but unfortunately I read them so long ago that most of the links between them are lost to me.

Don't see what all the fuss is about. The information on the part the sappers played in the war was interesting, and the emotional divide between those who had lived in and experienced the war first-hand and their family members and others in England was well portrayed. But in no way did I find it the moving, triumphant, literary tour-de-force as which it is so frequently described.The first part of the book, containing some objectionable sex scenes, could easily be skipped -- you wouldn't miss anything, just know that <(view spoiler)[> Stephen Wrayford at 20 years of age is sent by his employer to Amiens to learn more about conditions in the textile trade there. While staying with a businessman he has an affair with Isabelle, said businessman's wife. She eventually leaves her (abusive) husband and her two step-children to live with Stephen, whom she then in turn abandons when she finds out she is pregnant by him....for reasons not fully explained. She doesn't tell him she's pregnant, leave a note, or have any further contact with him. Now you're ready to move on to section two, if you must. You can thank me later. Want the rest of the book? Stephen survives lots of terrible battles, losing most of his comrades. He finally is rescued by Germans from an underground tunnel which had been blown and trapped him, and which he managed to stay alive in for a week or so, thanks to a tunneler called Jack Firebrace, who, though badly wounded, helps keep Stephen alive by telling him the layout of the tunnels and how to set a charge to draw the attention of those up above. By the time the Germans get him out (while searching for their own) the front has passed them by. After the war, Stephen ends up marrying Jeanne, Isabelle's sister, they raise Francoise (yes, Stephen has finally found out about his offspring) after the death of Isabelle to Spanish influenza in Germany where she has gone to live with her German lover. She got around. Years later, his somewhat dense granddaughter finds the coded diaries Stephen kept during his time in France and the war and gets them decoded. She has a baby (with a married man) and names him after the son(who died during the war of diptheria while he was at the front) of Jack Firebrace. The end. You can thank me again now. (hide spoiler)]

The sheer quality of Faulkes' writing is so good it really doesn't seem to matter that I'm reading this trilogy back to front.Interesting foreword in which the author details his personal journey in researching the Great War. Fabulous read.

I resisted loving this book for as long as I could, for a variety of reasons--foremost among them my sense of its being a little too neat, a little too dramatically contrived--but in the end I gave in. I loved this book, for all its flaws and for all my lack of real interest in its protagonist.When I was reading the first section (approximately one hundred pages, prewar), I wrote of it: "Faulks cites a number of nineteenth-century French authors as influences, and Flaubert in particular is evident in this book--and not just because of its early setting (France) and subject (adultery). It's very sensual, very attuned to physicality, and very involved with the way that convention wars with romanticism. The prose itself speaks to that contrast: often formalized, restrained, but just barely covering the narrative surge beneath."But it was, unexpectedly, in the descriptions of men at war that Faulks came into his own. The staging of the night before the Somme in particular was brutally effective, and the relationships between the soldiers were compelling. Faulks did his research, too; perhaps sometimes a little too obviously, since there were moments when I felt as though I was reading 
The Great War and Modern Memory
, but overall it was a fair trade-off for capturing the texture of the era.Although I thought the last few pages worked, in general I remain unimpressed by the contemporary sections tacked on toward the end. As a rule they weren't as engaging as the trench scenes, and the technique of framing the story with a modern-day search for a family's past is already overused in historical novels.But for all that, I loved this book. Enough that, like the Sunday Express reviewer, "as I finished it I turned to the front to start again." If you know how neurotic I am about constantly pushing ahead to new books, you'll understand what an endorsement that is.

For some time I've been meaning to read a highly-regarded World War I novel written by a writer whose first name is Sebastian, so when I discovered this novel on the shelf of my family's summer house, I figured this was it. There was, after all, a front cover rave from Simon Schama's New Yorker review and a back cover notice that it was "#1 international bestseller," along with more rave words from the NYT and LAT book reviews. But from the first page, I knew I had to be mistaken. The writing was too wooden, too awkward, for the kind of regard I had in mind. Turns out I was thinking of Sebastian Barry's A Long Long Way, which was shortlisted for the Booker and is now sitting atop my wishlist on Amazon.So Birdsong was a disappointment from the get go, but I finished it. The novel has a Now story and a Then story. The Then thread follows a young Englishman, Stephen Wraysford, from a 1910 love affair in France through the horrific trenches and tunnels of World War I. The Now story is set in 1978 in London and follows 30-something Elizabeth Benson, an unmarried career woman with a married lover and a mother sporting the very French name of Francoise. Beyond the awkward writing, my major gripe with this book is one I have with many novels nowadays: At 482 pages, it's simply too long. The tedium and unspeakable horror of the trenches does not have to be re-enacted on the page to get the point across. A handful of well-written scenes could have made the point more bracingly, but Faulk's endless reiteration wound up dulling my outrage at the seemingly endless and utterly senseless atrocity endured by the trench warriors. The Now story moves along much more briskly, but I found Elizabeth to be a very cold character, one who interested me clinically but didn't grab me emotionally. Still, I found the way things wrapped up satisfying. However, I won't be adding other titles by this Sebastian to my wishlist.

My first foray into the writing of Sebastian Faulks took me to a faraway land in France. The story begins with a bit of a love story when Stephen goes from London to France to learn the textile trade. Meeting a woman named Isabelle, he falls in love. Fast forward a bit to 1917 and WWI and we find our young hero, Stephen, fighting the Germans in the trenches in the French countryside. Firsthand I learned the ins and outs of trench warfare where young men were sent to march forward and forward bravely while bullets and mortar threatened their tender lives. This book is gritty and realistic. If you've ever wondered what life in WWI was like, this book transports you straight to the front line. Have you ever wondered why a certain friend or relative refuses to talk about a war in which they participated, this book will tell you why. Crazy thing war, horrible, misleading, deadly and hellish but so many return again and again to the front lines and the action, and once more this book will tell you why. After the horrors of war and the things the young men see and do, society, love and life is never the same. It's so very hard to connect with anyone else when you've been through it all.Even though this book has a dash of love and a lot of war, it's a tender story of a man who was orphaned when young and led a wandering life and a strong will to survive and to perhaps, feel love again.While the mortars are going off during WWI, Stephen's granddaughter in the future, is searching for him and trying and find out more about him as the story unfolds. His notebooks are all she has to go on and they are in secret code which has to be cracked if she is to know anything about this mysterious man whom she never met. And as his life unfolds, we witness the accounts of tunneling, and trench warfare of the first world war.Highly recommend - for those who wish to learn about what has gone before and how high the cost of our freedom was.

Several months since I read the novel, I recall the primary level of incident in this novel, the trench and tunnel warfare that English officer Wraysford experienced. Then there’s some secondary or tertiary business with the contemporary granddaughter who is trying to discover and understand something of her grandmother and grandfather. Then there is all the melodrama, which begins the novel and flows throughout: Wraysford, a young Englishman of promise, risen from his born class by education and sponsorship, who mucks things up with the daughter of the French businessman in whose home he’s staying with while doing professional research, so that he returns to England in disgrace, and for whom the outbreak of war provides an immediate escape, and a new chance to find his love...The most effecting episode I recall was of his fellow officer and his return home on leave. While that officer sought some sort of kind word from his patrician parents, they voiced only trite complaints about the inconvenience of the war, how they were obliged to put up with things, little realizing (or caring) in their stupid, contemptuous blinkered way that their son’s life-and-death part in the war was not the same thing as abstaining from an extra sugar cube at tea time. That particular episode is for me at the heart of the novel—confirmed by the presence of the granddaughter to discover and revitalize the past—which purpose is to unveil the bloody horror of the war, its emotional numbing, and society’s incomprehension of the soldier’s lot. The granddaugher reveals to us that some survivors, as exemplified by Wrayford, were able to re-kindle (through the mysteries and ministrations of love, atonement, sacrifice, forgiveness, grace) emotional means to carry on carrying on. Wraysford is portrayed as one of the lucky ones, given a melodramatic, loving means to survive; if only all veterans were lucky enough to have such backstories!

Sometimes a book can be condemned purely by association. Birdsong was a book that was nominated among the greatest books of the twentieth century, and even had a programme dedicated to it. Unfortunately the choice of presenter advocating the book was former Conservative party leader, William Hague.Hague is remembered (if at all) as the Tory leader who was easily defeated by Labour, and later held a cabinet position in which his main achievements were…well, I can’t think of any. I best remember his leadership campaign which was based on opposition to the European single currency. There were good reasons for not signing up to the euro of course, but Hague seemed to think it was enough to hold up a coin with the Queen’s head on, and say ‘Look at it!’ in a misty-eyed way. Only a Tory would imagine that people would get sentimental over currency.Of course it may be unfair to judge Faulks purely by his choice of defender, as there have been many great works by writers of conservative leanings. Even Shakespeare had a book written about him by our current Tory PM.Still the very name Sebastian Faulks (both forename and surname) suggest someone of posh upbringing. I was not too surprised to see that his brother was a Tory minister. Faulks does seem to have worked for The Independent, a pseudo-liberal newspaper that has some good intentions. He also appears to have added his signature to a newspaper letter where various people called for Scotland to remain part of the United Kingdom. Of course everyone is allowed an opinion on the subject, but to sign something that amounts to a petition to oppose another country making its own autonomous decision hardly reeks of progressive thinking.None of this tells us whether Birdsong is any good, but it sets up some of the background for how we might imagine Faulks feels about the issues in the book. Birdsong is essentially a war book. It is concerned with the First World War, as experienced by a number of the soldiers, one in particular. But is it a pro-war or anti-war book?By way of digression, we may well ask whether any story about war is not automatically both pro-war and anti-war at the same time. The anti-war book cannot help making war look exciting. Even the more gruesome elements of an anti-war book are not much different than the more gung-ho pro-war books.It may seem strange to imagine any book as pro-war, since war is felt to be a bad thing. Still there are books that glorify war and fighting, or which defend a particular war. Pro-war stories more often come out during a war as propaganda, but can be offered in peacetime by people wishing to praise soldiers and their role in a war.Still the pro-war story cannot help being partly anti-war. The fighting is gruelling. Decent soldiers die or suffer horrible injuries. Leaders and even the soldiers on the ground are forced to make terrible decisions that raise ethical problems.Before offering my verdict on Birdsong, it might be necessary to say what it is about. The main character in Birdsong is Stephen Wraysford. In the first part of Birdsong he is in France, which is where most of the book will be set.Stephen is staying with the Azaires, a middle-class family. A strike is taking place among industrial workers, which will not end in victory for them. Azaire is determined to see the workers accept poorer conditions. This is only the backdrop to a more personal event. Stephen has an affair with Azaire’s wife, Isabelle. He briefly persuades her to leave her abusive husband, but the pregnant Isabelle decides to return to him.The rest of the book is divided between two time zones. During World War One, Stephen is an officer who witnesses much slaughter and appalling conditions. He briefly gets to see Isabelle once more but she is now committed to a German officer. Meanwhile in the 1970s, Stephen’s grand-daughter Elizabeth is investigating her his time during the war, whilst also getting pregnant with a child that is the product of adultery, though in this case she is seeing a married man.The sections in the 1970s are less well-liked by readers, and with good reason. Not all readers are convinced by Elizabeth’s character. The more serious problem is that they break up the narrative concerning Stephen, and give us irrelevant accounts of how he will be viewed many years later. We may see this as being about the reconstruction of history, if we like. If so, it rests on an optimistic belief that the past can be reconstructed as truth.I would have happily dispensed with all the 1970s passages but that is not to say that I am enthusiastic about the earlier part of the book either. Faulks gives us the thoughts and feelings of his characters, and yet I never really had a strong sense of their personalities. They seem colourless.Indeed Stephen has very little personality. He is kind and compassionate in his way, but also impassive and lacking any warmth. No wonder Isabelle went back to her husband. While Azaire is not a nice man, she does at least have a warm family to help bring up her child rather than the distant affections of Stephen.This aloofness applies to Stephen’s relations with the world at large too. He observes the striking workers, but does not interest himself passionately in their grievances. He is horrified by war, but never loves the soldiers and treats the war as if it is a game, an experiment in how bad men can get under pressure.Perhaps something of this dispassionate nature comes from Faulks himself. Faulks is vaguely sympathetic to the strikers, as long as the hotheads are excluded, but he does not seem especially concerned whether they win or lose.There is a similar attitude towards the suffering of the soldiers in World War One. Faulks portrays the sufferings and horrifying deaths of the soldiers in graphic detail, but there is no real sense of outrage. Indeed so many gruesome tales in one place is desensitising. I cannot remember any individual awful detail in Birdsong because Faulks piles the horror stories too high.What I feel when I hear such stories is compassion and anger. Anger at the leaders who forced so many young men to lose their innocence, limbs, lives or sanity just to defend a few vested interests at home. Perhaps even anger at the soldiers for allowing themselves to be manipulated into prejudiced attitudes against others based on a few arbitrary national boundaries, themselves decided by war. It is absurd to hate the Germans as if they are not merely the same as the British, another collection of soldiers misled into bigotry against their enemy in order to serve the national interest of a small number of people, none of whom are fighting.That perspective is missing in Faulks. He sees the pity and sadness of war, but does not question its necessity. The sacrifices may be appalling, but this does not cause Faulks to see anything wrong with the cause of so much pain.

This book has been attempted by me many times over the years; I think I first started it when I was 15 and I couldn’t seem to get past the first 100 pages, but finally I have achieved the impossible and finished the book!To be honest, at 15 I think I was a little young for the book, not least because of the explicit sex in the first 100 pages, but also I didn’t know much about WW1 until my A-levels, where I had to study a range of WW1 literature, as the battlefield descriptions and the tunnels can get a little confusing. Anyway, as an adult it was okay, I think it would’ve been better if it concentrated on the war, Wraysford’s soap opera back story didn’t really help me connect to him and I preferred Firebrace even though we were only told about his ‘life’ back home through letters and recollections. What really, really annoyed me was the 1970’s interludes where an idiotic woman cipher, a supposedly successful businesswoman, suddenly decides to investigate WW1 for no apparent reason, later vaguely relating her quest to an absent grandfather and wanting to feel ‘connected’. These bits infuriated me, not least because it felt like Faulks was treating us like fools, in a ‘I’m going to make WW1 relevant to you blah blah blah’ way. I don’t consider myself an idiot and I have enough imagination to realise the tremendous sacrifice made by all involved that I don’t need a present day cipher reducing it down to an unemotional ‘who do think you are’ exercise. I would’ve liked an actual account of what happened to Wraysford, and for it not to be revealed in the reported drivel of the most uninspiring woman in literature.So the war bits are ‘great’ in a harrowing way, rest of it pure drivel. A more poignant WW1 book by far is Strange Meeting.

Another of those books I thought would be better. It started out strong. But then it kind of died. I mean, when all those quotes talk about OMG WHAT AN EPIC LOVE STORY!!! and the love story cannot even touch the hem of epicness, something is wrong. I checked to see if all the review blurbs were from men, but some women apparently also fail to know what a real love story is (hint: it’s not a torrid love affair That Society Disapproves Of followed by the woman leaving the man when she gets pregnant and hiding the baby’s existence from him and never seeing him again and Jesus Christ, I realized I just described the (not really romantic) romance in Possession as well! THIS IS A HORRIBLE PLOT LINE THAT SHOULDN’T BE USED ONCE, MUCH LESS TWICE!!!). Ahem. The plotline of Stephen/Isabelle’s daughter was pretty pointless. Also, she was dumb. Her comments about WWI and how shocked (shocked!) she was that battlefields could be in cities and not just on fields made me wonder (1) if she had ever been to school (2) if she was brain dead. And her affair with a married man (the fact that he had a wife was his responsibility, not hers!) did not make me like her any better. As to the WWI part, which is why I think this story gets so much attention...it’s okay. Stephen is pretty much dead inside by this time, and it also causes the story to feel a bit dead. And there’s a lot of jumping around in POVs and I’m sorry, but I just could not keep track of the characters, especially since they kept dying, so it was really hard to care about anyone (Stephen I hated for most of the book, but sadly he lived). There are far superior war books out there (Cold Mountain, for one, handled war and its effects much better, though I hated the female POV in that one).

Having just finished this much recommended book I am still reeling from its impact. It was a struggle to read. Not the early chapters set in Amiens before the war where the ill-fated love affair between Stephen and Isabelle races away. No, in those early chapters I turned the pages avidly, but then came the chapters in the trenches,down the tunnels and into the razor wire. It was in one of the tunnel scenes towards the end of the book that I completely understood Stephen's tenacity and bravery as a soldier. As a reader who shares Stephen’s bird phobia, I physically felt his torture when capturing the canary in the tunnel. As I read ...“The small canary suspended from his mouth made feeble movements and its yellow feathers protruded from the handkerchief to brush softly against his face. He closed his eyes and pushed onwards. He longed for the mud and the stench, for the sound of shells (p. 306)" my heart raced and my breath quickened, a true nightmare.So it’s taken me a while, not because I wasn’t absorbed by this incredible work of historical fiction, rather because it was too real, too ugly, too horrific. The horror of this war was depicted so graphically that my night time reading was put aside for something lighter and less likely to induce nightmares. For the past couple of days I’ve devoted some daytime reading to finishing Birdsong. I’m so glad it’s over. Quite often great stories are reduced by their conclusion but not Birdsong. The ending is, in my opinion, perfect. It echoes back through the decades fulfilling a promise made in the trenches, while the reader is left to imagine how the characters lives will resume. Five stars from me. Tragically memorable.

3.5 Stars...With Birdsong Sebastian Faulks brings the reader right into the trenches of WWI. We are going over the wall, walking senselessly towards the enemy and watching our friends get blown in half or jerkily dance to the impact of bullets. We are covered in lice that we burn in the seams of our clothes with matches for entertainment. We are wet, cold, terrified, claustrophobic. We are emotionally numb from the sheer volume of dead bodies surrounding us. Birdsong has some incredibly powerful wartime stories and although the book claims to be about Love and War, be prepared that it is mostly about war. Fortunately, those are the strongest sections of this book. The descriptions on the tunnels and the team who went from digging the London Underground to digging the tunnels in France was fascinating. While it's not always easy or enjoyable to read about war, it was definitely an education that I appreciated.When the book is about love it is much less compelling. Stephen Wraysford meets an older married woman and without a lot of discussion, they fall into bed (why do these kinds of stories always revolve around awakening a frigid woman to the joys of sex). This relationship creates a thread through the rest of the book and leads to some brief "modern day" chapters about a woman researching her grandfather's WWI past. These chapters didn't ring true for me and seemed to take away from the gritty realism of the battlefield but I suppose they give the book a reason for telling the story and give the author a way to eventually sum up Stephen's future for the reader. Overall I found this book uneven. I never felt very connected to the characters but the war segments were compelling and worth the effort.

Birdsong tells the story of a young English man Stephen Wraysford, who goes to France on business a few years before World war I and has a passionate affair with his boss’s wife Isabelle, then when the war starts he enlists. Even in this early part of the novel, the other characters are more extreme and fleshed out than the hero (antihero) .It took me a while to get into his character, but over the course of the book through his relationships with the tunnellers, and memories from his childhood we get a better picture of the man. The scenes set in the trenches, are horrific and show the effects on the men as they become detached to death. An interesting aspect of the story was the tunnellers whose job was digging the tunnels under no-man’s land and laying the mines. The character Jack Firebrace, who leaves a wife, and dying child in London I found very moving, his relationship with Stephen starts with Jack being court martialled and ends with them fighting for their lives in a tunnel. The intense friendships of the men who live so closely in awful conditions, contrasts with the rather cold character of Stephen. A lot of reviewers dislike the later section dealing with Wraysford’s grandaughter in 1978 searching for clues to her grandfathers past. I thought it was ok, as it showed how her generation knew practically nothing about World war I and the scene where she meets with an elderly WWI veteran whose mind was still replaying events was very affecting. Overall I enjoyed this book and found the last third riveting, I suppose on the whole, this book is about love, and the human will to survive against hardship.
